zone.figDesc: Only the lower C♯ is tied between measures 10 and 11.
The accidental is missing on the G♯ in the upper staff.

annot.p: A1 (measure 3) and EN have G♯, while ES1 and EB have G♮ (with no accidental).
A1 (measure 8) and EB have A♮ (with no accidental in A1), while ES1 has A♯ (with no accidental).
EN and EB have B, while ES1 has G, which is surely an error. The passage is different in A1, but the theme occurs with B in measure 16.
In A1 (measures 19-21) and EB, both the ties in measure 9 continue to the first beat of measure 11, while in ES1, only the lower C♯ is tied between measures 10 and 11.
A1 (measure 23) and EB have B♮, while ES1 has B♯ (with no accidental).
A1 (measure 25) and EB have D♯, while ES1 has D♮ (with no accidental).
In ES1 and EB, the accidental is missing on the G♯ in the upper staff. A1 (measure 25) is unclear.
EB has D♮, while ES1 has D♯ (with no accidental), which is surely an error. A1 (measure 25) is unclear.
Twice in this beat, A1 (measure 26, though slightly different) and EB have E♮, while ES1 has E♯ (with no accidental).
EB has E♯, while ES1 and EN have E♮ (with no accidental). The corresponding passage in A1 (starting in measure 29) has neither, and has a somewhat different harmonic structure.

The reading with E♯ maintains the parallelism of the passage: each chromatically descending diminished chord can be seen as a dominant minor ninth whose root appears in the left hand, and the same four-note interval sequence occurs each time. The E♮ reading does not fit this pattern.
A1 (measure 30) and EB have E♮, while ES1 has E♯ (with no accidental).
A1 (measure 30) and EB have G♮, while ES1 has G♯ (with no accidental).
In ES1 and EB, the accidental is missing on the G♯ in the upper staff. A1 has a different structure here.
The chord is staccato in ES1, but not in EB. A1 (measure 40) has a different structure here.
